conversations.content: What is the main topic of the article published on Oct 16, 2024?

The main topic of the article published on Oct 16, 2024, is the colonial nature of the Zionist regime and the United States of America. The article discusses how understanding this colonial nature is essential to ending Zionism. It highlights that the Zionist regime is viewed as the last colonial project of the settler colonial type and emphasizes the solidarity between nations oppressed by colonialism and the Palestinian people.
Who is the author of the article discussing the colonial nature of the Zionist regime and the United States?
The author of the article discussing the colonial nature of the Zionist regime and the United States is Hakimeh Saqhaye-Biria, Assistant Professor at Tehran University.
What is the significance of understanding the colonial nature of the Zionist regime and the United States?

Understanding the colonial nature of the Zionist regime and the United States is significant because it is the first step necessary to end Zionism in the world. The article highlights that many anti-colonial thinkers view colonialism as a current reality seen in the nature and behavior of the Zionist regime, which is considered the last colonial project of the settler colonial type that must end.
How do anti-colonial thinkers view colonialism in the context of the Zionist regime?

Anti-colonial thinkers view colonialism not as something of the past but as a current reality seen in the very nature and behavior of the Zionist regime. They consider the illegitimate Zionist regime as the last colonial project of the settler colonial type that must end. This view emphasizes the ongoing struggle for the freedom of Palestine and the deep sense of identification and empathy with the Palestinian people among the nations oppressed by colonialism.
What is the legacy of colonialism for the people of colonized countries and indigenous people in Western countries?

The legacy of colonialism is still tangible for the people of the colonized countries as well as for the colored and indigenous people affected by the history of colonialism in Western countries. This legacy includes a deep sense of identification and empathy with the Palestinian people, as the issue is more than just a few hundred square kilometers of Palestinian land. It represents the complete transition from open colonialism in the world to a world free of colonialism.
Why is achieving victory in the struggle for the cause of Palestine considered significant?

Achieving victory in the struggle for the cause of Palestine is considered significant because it is seen as the victory of all mankind in confronting the miserable history of Western colonialism. It is considered the last stage of moving beyond more than 500 years of Western colonial order.
What is the conceptual framework used to express solidarity with the Palestinian people?

The conceptual framework used to express solidarity with the Palestinian people is the comparison of Israeli settler colonialism with American settler colonialism. This comparison is happening today among the target communities of the two nations, and it has led to the expression of solidarity with the Palestinian people using this framework.
What is the awakening of Western countries, especially among the young generation, in relation to the Zionist regime attributed to?

The awakening of Western countries, especially among the young generation, in relation to the Zionist regime is largely attributed to the emergence of an ideational movement in the world. This movement defines the Zionist regime as a regime based on settler colonialism that is systematically committing the crime of apartheid. It has created a distinct discourse about why and how to end Zionism and has opened the space for the people of Western countries to express their support for the Palestinian people in unprecedented ways.
What is settler colonialism and what are its integral parts?

Settler colonialism occurs when colonizers invade and occupy a land in order to permanently replace the existing society with their own. Two integral parts of settler colonialism are land usurpation and the elimination of the indigenous people. This elimination can happen through complete annihilation of the population or through population reduction, territorial limitation based on systematic repression, forced removal, and cultural elimination of communities under the domination of settler colonialism.
What does Patrick Wolfe refer to as 'the logic of elimination' in settler colonialism?

Patrick Wolfe, an Australian professor of history and the founder of settler colonial studies, refers to 'the logic of elimination' as a phenomenon in settler colonialism where aggression is a 'structure not an event.' In this logic, settler colonizers come to stay and destroy the native society to replace it with their own. This logic has two aspects: the physical eradication of the indigenous people and the cultural genocide of the target society after destroying the structures of the previous society.
What is the significance of Theodor Herzl's manifesto in the context of settler colonialism?

Theodor Herzl, the founder of Zionism, is quoted in Patrick Wolfe's work as saying, 'If I wish to substitute a new building for an old one, I must demolish before I construct.' This quote highlights the destructive nature of settler colonialism, where the old society is demolished to make way for a new colonial society.
What is one of the reasons for the United States' support for the Zionist regime?

One of the reasons for the United States' support for the Zionist regime is the common cultural heritage based on settler colonialism. This common heritage is increasingly receiving the attention of historians and experts on West Asian issues. Essentially, the last example of settler colonialism in the world (the Zionist regime) is committing heinous crimes against humanity with the support of the first example of settler colonialism (the United States of America).
How does Mahmood Mamdani compare the settler colonialism of the Zionist regime with the American model?

Mahmood Mamdani suggests that the settler colonialism of the Zionist regime is more inspired by the American model than the South African model of apartheid. The Zionist regime has been using the dual policy of genocide and encampment of natives in reservation camps, similar to what was used in the United States against Native Americans. This policy has been pursued by the Zionist regime not only at the beginning of its establishment but also throughout its existence.
What is the point of similarity between the Palestinians and the Native Americans according to Mahmood Mamdani?

The point of similarity between the Palestinians and the Native Americans, according to Mahmood Mamdani, is the use of the dual policy of genocide and encampment of natives in reservation camps. However, while Native Americans lived in a world where colonialism was on the rise, the Palestinians are now reaching the end of a period of five centuries of Western domination, a period that began in 1492. Mamdani believes that Palestinian political isolation in the Middle East is gradually joining history and that it is now possible to imagine a free Palestine.
How did the American colonial society view black slaves and Native Americans differently?

The American colonial society viewed black slaves as labor and economic capital but viewed Native Americans as a source of land. Therefore, the confrontation with the blacks was focused on individual dominance, while the confrontation with the Indians was focused on ethnic-tribal dominance. The structures and tools of systematic repression were formed in different ways. According to Mahmood Mamdani, 'In the language of the law, the African American was like a dog that could be tamed, but the Indian American was like a cat that remained wild.'
What is exceptional about the United States of America in terms of decolonization?

What is exceptional about the United States of America is that it has not yet raised the issue of decolonization in the public domain. According to Mahmood Mamdani, the United States is not the first modern anti-colonial revolution but the first settler-colonial state, a state that resulted in the conquest and destruction of Native American lives.
What did the apartheid government of South Africa model on the United States?

The apartheid government of South Africa modeled two institutions on the United States. The first was the concentration of Natives in tribal homelands, which was inspired by the reservations built to confine Indian tribes in mid-nineteenth century America. The second was the technology known as the PASS system, which was first created in the slave plantations of the American South with the aim of controlling the movement of slaves. This system exposed them to a variety of abuses and was later used in South Africa and now in the Zionist regime.
How were Native Americans treated in the American Constitution?

Native Americans were considered 'savages' in the Declaration of Independence and were never recognized as a minority with basic political rights in the American Constitution. Although they were recognized as citizens in 1924, as long as they live in designated areas under self-governing rule and adhere to their own way of life, they do not enjoy the civil liberties guaranteed by the US Constitution. They possess political rights but not civil rights and are subject to congressional rules without having representation in Congress. Even the Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not apply to Native Americans living in certain areas.
What is the significance of the American Revolution of 1776 in the context of settler colonialism?

The American Revolution of 1776, which led to the independence of the white population living in America from England, is significant in the context of settler colonialism because it was not an anti-colonial revolution but rather a movement toward the expansion of American settler colonialism. From this point of view, American independence is similar to the independence of white South Africans in 1910 and the independence of Zionists in 1948. In all three cases, it was a rebellion against the native populations living in these areas and the establishment of the settler-colonial structure in it.
What is Mahmood Mamdani's view on the comparison between Apartheid South Africa and Israel?

Mahmood Mamdani argues that Apartheid South Africa was not a fitting lens through which to understand Israel. Instead, he suggests that the settler colonial United States is being modeled in the Zionist regime. He points out that, as in North America, the settler in Israel is not interested in Palestinians as a source of labor; they want their land. Mamdani cites an exchange in The Jerusalem Post where a member of the Knesset compared the treatment of Bedouins to the treatment of Native Americans by the United States.
What is the significance of the two-state solution proposed by the United States for the Palestinians?

The two-state solution proposed by the United States for the Palestinians is significant because it is similar to the approach the United States had with the Native Americans. The pattern of limited self-governance in limited territories that was imposed on Native Americans through ethnic cleansing and forced migration is the same as the granting of sovereignty over limited territories to the Palestinians. This approach suggests a similar pattern of limited self-governance in limited territories.
What is the significance of the year 1948 for Palestinians and Mexicans in the US Southwest?

The year 1948 was the Nakba, the year of catastrophe for Palestinians. For Mexicans in the US Southwest, Nakba came in 1848, with Mexico’s loss of almost half of its territory. According to Rosara Sánchez and Beatrice Pita, there is much that the people of Mexican origin in the United States share with the Palestinians living in Israel as well as those living in the West Bank and Gaza. They share the dispossession of land and a history of living as second-class citizens under a hegemonic state power imposed by historical circumstance.
What is the common denominator between Palestinians and American Indians or Americans of Mexican origin?

The common denominator between Palestinians and American Indians or Americans of Mexican origin is the dispossession of land and a history of living as second-class citizens under a hegemonic state power imposed by historical circumstance. However, the commonality ends there because American settler colonialism happened at the height of colonialism in the world, while Israeli settler colonialism is taking place during the decline of colonial powers and global rethinking of destructive colonial structures.
What is the significance of ending the Zionist regime in the context of settler colonialism?

Ending the Zionist regime in the context of settler colonialism is significant because it represents the last page of the history of settler colonialism. Every blow that each of us gives to this colonial regime to end it is a service to all humanity as we aim to arrive at a decolonized world in the near future. This is the only just resolution to the Palestinian question, and the unity of humanity around this cause is very much possible given the global awakening of oppressed populations.

The global awakening of oppressed populations is significant in the context of the Palestinian question because it highlights the unity of humanity around this cause. What is the significance of the PASS system in the context of settler colonialism?

The PASS system is significant in the context of settler colonialism because it was first created in the slave plantations of the American South with the aim of controlling the movement of slaves. This system exposed them to a variety of abuses and was later used in South Africa and now in the Zionist regime. The PASS system is a technology of Native control that was produced as part of settler colonialism in North America and has been modeled by other settler colonial regimes.
What is the significance of the reservation system in the context of settler colonialism?

The reservation system is significant in the context of settler colonialism because it was the prototype concentration camp from which the Nazis drew inspiration. The reservation system was built to confine Indian tribes in mid-nineteenth century America and was later modeled by the apartheid government of South Africa. The reservation system is an example of the defining institutions of settler colonialism that were produced as technologies of Native control in North America.
